awd_titl_txt: Targeted Infusion Project: Infusion of Computational Science Based Data Analytics Coursework and Research to Strengthen and Enrich the Lane College Undergraduate Chemistry Program
awd_abstract_narration:
The Historically Black Colleges and Universities Undergraduate Program (HBCU-UP) through Targeted Infusion Projects supports the development, implementation, and study of evidence-based innovative models and approaches for improving the preparation and success of HBCU undergraduate students so that they may pursue STEM graduate programs and/or careers. The project at Lane College will provide students with exposure to skill-building techniques that will benefit them throughout their matriculation as well as beyond their baccalaureate studies through introduction to computational chemistry and data analytics, research opportunities and scholarly engagement/dissemination opportunities.  

As the interest in STEM majors has grown over the years, so has the need for non-traditional, interdisciplinary preparation of students working towards the baccalaureate.  The overall goal of the project is to increase the interest, preparation and inclusion of students from groups underrepresented in the field of chemistry, specifically computational chemistry and related areas. This goal will be accomplished by 1) exposing and training students in computational science techniques; 2) increasing the number of students conducting scientific research through mentored research experiences; 3) encouraging the engagement of undergraduate students into scientific discourse and dissemination of data and 4) increasing the number of students attending graduate school for a chemistry-related discipline. This project will serve as a case study on the preparation of students who, historically, have not been exposed to STEM education or research opportunities. These efforts will also increase the body of scientific knowledge in the areas of computational chemistry and data science.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

por.por_cntn:
Lane College is a Historically Black College located in Jackson, Tennessee that predominately serves a population of students who are vastly underrepresented and underserved across STEM fields. Lane centers its mission to "develop the whole student" through student-centered approaches to learning, ultimately aiming to unlock "The Power of Potential" in each student. The aim of this project was to improve the quality of Lane’s undergraduate chemistry program through coursework enhancement and the addition of research and scholarly engagement opportunities.

During the project period the chemistry department successfully offered new coursework to introduce computational methodology, as well as research courses to allow students opportunities to engage in research throughout the semester. As a result of the challenges brought on and/or exacerbated by the COVID-19 pandemic, a virtual learning experience for research students was also developed in this period. These challenges also led to a larger student group than initially expected as computational activities were integrated into the broader chemistry curriculum.

Through the project students also had opportunities to engage with professional chemistry conferences as well as graduate preparation efforts.

 

Intellectual Merit:

This project supports the infusion of research-based opportunities within the broader chemistry curriculum to offer research exposure to students. This helped the students to hone their scientific literacy and critical thinking skills. The most impactful part of the project appeared to be the student’s exposure to scholarly conferences. In particular, The Annual Conference of The National Organization for the Professional Advancement of Black Chemists and Chemical Engineers (NOBCChE) and The Conference on Current Trends in Computational Chemistry (CCTCC). In these spaces the students saw representation they had not yet seen in the field and as such reported developing a sense of belonging in the scientific community.

Given the timing of the project (during the COVID-19 pandemic), and amongst the limitations in access to in-person work this also made an essential case to students the relevance of computational education as well as the application of computational chemistry to a vast number of fields.

Lastly students who engaged in the project both throughout the cohort and through course-based research experiences have begun ongoing work to better understand Catechin structures and their properties using computational methods.

 

Broader Impacts:

Though impacting a smaller population at Lane, through project activities and exposure, student participants were equipped with knowledge, essential skills, and research skills that are highly coveted in the scientific world. All student participants successfully matriculated through the undergraduate chemistry program. One student is currently enrolled in a Pharm.D program, one student is in the process of pursuing graduate studies in chemistry with focus on computational chemistry, and one student used their skills to enter directly into the workforce outside of chemistry. Faculty involved in the project developed a research experience and training curriculum and a research mentoring process that will extend past the life of the award period. This project was also a major contributor to the advancement of underrepresented faculty, who received promotion in rank at their respective institution.

 

 


Last Modified: 01/19/2024
Modified by: Aminah Farrakhan-Gooch
